html.p: A field is, essentially, a set in which one can add, subtract, multiply, and divide any two elements (other than dividing by zero). The formal definition is below.

The field that we will most commonly use in this course is the set of real numbers [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R[/mathjaxinline]. Other fields include the set of complex numbers [mathjaxinline]\mathbb C[/mathjaxinline], the set of rational numbers [mathjaxinline]\mathbb Q[/mathjaxinline], and the integers modulo a prime [mathjaxinline]p[/mathjaxinline].

div.p: A field is a set [mathjaxinline]F[/mathjaxinline] together with binary operations [mathjaxinline]+, \cdot[/mathjaxinline] on [mathjaxinline]F[/mathjaxinline] which satisfy the following conditions:

li.p: Addition is associative and commutative; that is, for all [mathjaxinline]a,b,c \in F[/mathjaxinline], we have [mathjaxinline]a+(b+c) = (a+b)+c[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]a+b = b+a[/mathjaxinline].
There is an element [mathjaxinline]0 \in F[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]a+0 = a[/mathjaxinline] for all [mathjaxinline]a \in F[/mathjaxinline].
For every [mathjaxinline]a\in F[/mathjaxinline], there is an element [mathjaxinline]-a \in F[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]-a + a = 0[/mathjaxinline].

Multiplication is associative and commutative; that is, for all [mathjaxinline]a,b,c \in F[/mathjaxinline], we have [mathjaxinline]a(bc) = (ab)c[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]ab = ba[/mathjaxinline].
There is a non-zero element [mathjaxinline]1 \in F[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]1a = a[/mathjaxinline] for all [mathjaxinline]a \in F[/mathjaxinline].
For every non-zero [mathjaxinline]a\in F[/mathjaxinline], there is an element [mathjaxinline]a^{-1}[/mathjaxinline] such that [mathjaxinline]a^{-1}a = 1[/mathjaxinline].
Multiplication distributes over addition; that is, for all [mathjaxinline]a,b,c \in F[/mathjaxinline], [mathjaxinline]a(b+c) = ab + ac[/mathjaxinline].
